--- In junit@y..., "dvydra2" <david@v...> wrote:
> Kent,
> 
> I agree with your position, however I am at a new job and there is 
an 
> existing body of tests that we would like to run within the JUnit 
> framework. These tests lean more towards being functional tests and 
> rely on multiple failures being handled correctly. There have been 
> several opinions on this list in support of multiple failures for 
> functional tests. 

I like multiple failures when I'm writing functional tests, too. 
That's a different problem than what is solved by JUnit.
 
> What I would like to know is the reason TestCase inherits from 
Assert 
> rather than delegates to it. If it delegated, we could subclass 
> TestCase to handle multiple failures and still use Assert for DbC.

History, in part. Assert and TestCase were once a single class. Then 
we noticed that assert* and fail* didn't depend on any instance 
state, so we could make them into their own class. By making them 
static we could make them easily accessible outside test cases 
without any cost within.

Can you write up the behavior you'd like to see as a test case? 
Perhaps it is possible to satisfy all constraints.

Kent
